questions.text: Which one of the following pressures is maintained by Carotid sinus baroreceptor:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mean blood pressure

 

Effect of hypovolemia or hypotension or common carotid artery occlusion → Reduction in perfusion pressure and fall in mean blood pressure of carotid sinus → baroreceptors lessen their discharge → medullary cardiovascular centre is inhibited → increase their drive to the sympathetic vasoconstriction and to the cardiac sympathetic fibers → increase BP and increase HR.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a 20-year history of alcohol use presents to the emergency department after experiencing an episode characterized by sudden muscle contractions, a brief period of unconsciousness, and involuntary jerking movements. According to his family, he stopped drinking alcohol two days ago. On examination, the patient is found to have hepatomegaly, blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg, a heart rate of 110/min, and a temperature of 100.2°F. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lorazepam

This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of an alcohol withdrawal seizure, which occurred after stopping alcohol consumption two days ago. The patient's vitals indicate elevated blood pressure, increased heart rate, and a mildly elevated temperature, which are consistent with alcohol withdrawal.

A. Benzodiazepines are the drugs of choice in patients with alcohol withdrawal. Lorazepam is a safer choice for this patient due to hepatomegaly and possible liver dysfunction, as lorazepam undergoes glucuronidation, a conjugation process that results in the formation of inactive metabolites. This process is less affected by liver dysfunction compared to the oxidative metabolism that other benzodiazepines, such as chlordiazepoxide, undergo.

B. Chlordiazepoxide, a long-acting benzodiazepine, can be used for treating alcohol withdrawal seizures. However, its use may not be advisable in patients with liver dysfunction due to its reliance on hepatic oxidative metabolism, which can be impaired in such cases. Additionally, its longer half-life poses a risk for accumulation and prolonged sedation, particularly in patients with liver dysfunction.

C. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant that can be used as an alternative treatment for alcohol withdrawal seizures, particularly in cases where benzodiazepines are contraindicated or not well tolerated. While it is effective in managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms and preventing seizures, benzodiazepines are generally considered the first-line treatment due to their rapid onset of action and efficacy.

D. Phenytoin is not the preferred choice for treating alcohol withdrawal seizures, as it is less effective in this context compared to benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Four days after undergoing laparotomy for duodenal ulcer perforation, patient is started on clear liquids. He complains of epigastric discomfort and bilious vomiting. Abdominal examination reveals generalized distension without tenderness. All of these will be done next in management except:
questions.solution:
Ans B. Stop oral and feed via NJ tube

  • The given clinical picture is suggestive of post-operative ileus.
  • Management: Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

choices.text: MRM in node negative patients
MRM in node positive patients

questions.text: In which of the given cases is this procedure usually performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. BCT in node negative patients

The following image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy:

  • First performed by Dr. Cabana for penile carcinoma
  • Sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node
  • Only done on node-negative tumors as a part of BCS/BCT. In node positive patients, BCT includes axillary lymph node clearance directly (without SLNB).
  • In MRM, axillary clearance is done irrespective of clinical nodal status.
  • Technique: methylene blue dye or radioisotope (technetium)-labelled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera).
  • The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed.
  • The combination of blue dye and technetium-labelled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabelled dye.

It is less effective than lidocaine for local anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the use of cocaine as a local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It has vasoconstrictive properties that help to reduce bleeding at the site of administration

Cocaine is a local anesthetic that has been used for many years due to its ability to produce rapid and profound anesthesia. It works by blocking the conduction of nerve impulses in the area where it is applied through blockade of sodium channels. Additionally, cocaine has vasoconstrictive properties that help to reduce bleeding at the site of administration. This is particularly useful in procedures such as nasal surgery, where bleeding can be a significant problem. Despite its effectiveness as a local anesthetic, the use of cocaine is limited due to its potential for abuse and addiction.

It causes hypertension by inhibition of norepinephrine at adrenergic terminals leading to sympathetic stimulation.

Option A: Cocaine is an ester local anesthetic

Option B: It is more potent than lignocaine for local anesthesia

Option D: It requires a prescription for use in medical settings.

choices.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in Dorsal root ganglion
Maculopapular rash is seen
Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Herpes zoster (Shingles)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maculopapular rash is seen

A maculopapular rash is not seen in herpes zoster (shingles).

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a Dermatomal / Segmental distribution.

The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.

 

 The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Reference:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 4.13 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Staghorn calculi of the kidneys

choices.text: Incision and drainage under general anaesthesia

questions.text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. USG revealed abscess cavity of 40 cc volume and 4 cm in diameter. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Suction catheter drainage

The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to carry on breastfeeding.

“In abscesses >3 cm in diameter or those containing more than 30 mL of pus (assessed on ultrasonography), a vacuum suction catheter is inserted under ultrasound guidance to drain the pus (Figure 58.24 and 58.5). The patient should be reviewed on alternate days by clinical examination and ultrasonography. Any residual collection should be aspirated. The antibiotics are modified according to the microbiological culture report. In patients with a suction drain, the catheter is irrigated with cold normal saline (cold to reduce pain) on each visit until complete resolution. Antibiotics should be continued for 14 days.

questions.text: Identify the device used in laparoscopic surgery in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CO2 insufflator

  • Device shows “Pressure” and “Flow” readings of a CO2 insufflator device, which controls the flow of CO2 in pneumoperitoneum.
  • Modern theatres are designed with moveable booms for video, diathermy and laparoscopic equipment with at least two high-resolution, high-definition (HD) or ultra-high-definition (4K) monitors, a carbon dioxide supply and flow monitor and appropriate audiovisual kit.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents for a routine dental procedure. The dentist administers lidocaine with epinephrine for local anesthesia. During the procedure, the patient becomes confused and agitated, and then has a tonic-clonic seizure. The healthcare provider immediately stops the procedure and recognizes the signs of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). The patient is managed with supportive care, including administration of intravenous lipid emulsion therapy, and the seizure is controlled with benzodiazepines. The patient recovers without any further complications. Which of the following is a common clinical presentation of LAST?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tonic-clonic seizures

  • Option A. Bradypnea - While respiratory depression is a sign of LAST, bradypnea is not a common clinical presentation of LAST.
  • Option B. Hypertension - Hypertension is not a common sign of LAST. In fact, LAST is more commonly associated with hypotension.
  • Option C. Tonic-clonic seizures - Tonic-clonic seizures are a common clinical presentation of LAST.
  • Option D. Nausea and vomiting - Nausea and vomiting are not specific signs of LAST. However, they may be seen as part of the prodrome or early stages of LAST.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with vaginal spotting. She has not had a period for 2 months and her UPT is positive. What is the minimum mean sac diameter measurement necessary to diagnose an anembryonic pregnancy with certainty?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 25mm

  • Guidelines for Early Pregnancy Loss Diagnosis

Sonographic Findings:

  • CRL ≥7 mm and no heartbeat
  • MSD 25 mm and no embryo
  • An initial US scan shows a gestational sac with yolk sac, and after ≥11 days no embryo with a heartbeat is seen
  • An initial US scan shows a gestational sac without a yolk sac, and after 2 weeks no embryo with a heartbeat is seen.
  • The embryo should be visible transvaginally once the mean sac diameter has reached 25 mm—otherwise the gestation is anembryonic.

 

Ref: Page 526, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the impression based on the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

  • The above ECG is suggestive of dextrocardia. The patient has a dominant R wave in V1 which would be consistent with all the options provided in the question. However, there is a rightward QRS and P wave axis, a deep S wave inlead I and dominant R wave in aVr which are highly unusual and should raise the suspicion of either erroneous upper limb lead transposition or dextrocardia.
  • The progressive diminution of the R waves on transition from lead V1 to V6 indicates dextrocardia.

questions.text: A 23y primigravida presents for induction of labor at 41 weeks. Her Bishop score is 3. You proceed with cervical ripening using the agent shown below. What group of drugs does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prostaglandins

  • The likely medicine shown here is PGE1 (misoprostol) which is a prostaglandin and is available as a tablet.
  • Other methods of induction:
    • PGE2 (Dinoprostone): this is available as an intracervical gel or a vaginal tablet. This is also a prostaglandin
    • Oxytocin: Injection
    • Mechanical methods: laminaria tents/ ARM/ sweeping of membranes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to right upper thigh region. On examination, patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. On exploration, superficial femoral artery was transected. Which of the following is the suture material to be used for vascular repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Polypropylene

  • Polypropylene (Prolene) suture is a monofilament non absorbable suture. It comprises of isotactic crystalline stereoisomer of polypropylene. It is blue in colour to enhance visibility. It elicits maximum tensile strength and minimal tissue reaction that does not cause tissue rupture.
  • It is preferred suture material for vascular anastomoses. It is neither absorbed not subjected to weakening by tissue enzymes, non-adhering, and biologically inert. Thus it is used for permanent fixtures.
  • Other uses are - general soft tissue approximation and ligation in cardiovascular, plastic, neurological surgeries and hernia repair
  • Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture. Copolymer of 90% glycol and 10% l-lactide. It retrains tensile strength of about 70% till 14 days after implantation, it completely absorbs within 56-70 days by simple hydrolysis.
  • Poldioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture composed of polyester - p –dioxanone.  It is suitable for cases where extended would support and strength are required. It retains about 70% of initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely absorbed within 180- 210 days.
  • Delayed absorbable sutures like Vicryl and PDS are preferred for biliary and urological anastomosis where there is risk of foreign body inflammation and stone formation.
  • Vicryl is also known as work-horse suture of general surgery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea. The healthcare provider orders oxygen therapy to improve the patient's oxygen saturation. The respiratory therapist explains the different oxygen delivery devices available and their respective Fio2 levels and suggests to use a device which looks like in the image below. Identify the maximum Fio2 given by this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 90%

Fio2 is the fraction of inspired oxygen delivered by an oxygen delivery device. The appropriate device and Fio2 level depend on the patient's clinical condition and oxygenation needs.

The image shown above is of a non-rebreather mask. A non-rebreather mask can deliver up to 90% Fio2. It is typically used for patients with severe hypoxemia or respiratory distress.

Note that the actual Fio2 delivered may vary depending on the patient's respiratory rate, tidal volume, and the flow rate of oxygen delivered by the device.

choices.text: Dilated capillary loops in nail fold can be seen
Heliotrope rash seen in this disease is associated with anti-Mi-2 antibodies.
Mechanic's hands can be seen in this disease
Muscle tenderness is common in this condition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with Erythema & purplish tinge on upper eyelids & Erythema over shawl area as shown in the image below. She also had significantly elevated serum Creatinine phosphokinase levels. Identify the false statement regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Muscle tenderness is common in this condition

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Dermatomyositis. Muscle tenderness is not common in this disorder.

An autoimmune condition called dermatomyositis (DM) primarily affects the skin and skeletal muscles.

The following list includes several dermatomyositis symptoms:

Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.

Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules that can appear over the elbow, knee, dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints.

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.
  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

Screening:  Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

Diagnosis: Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

Gottron's papule, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign are associated with anti-Mi2 antibodies.

Mechanic hand, Myositis, and ILD (Interstitial Lung Disease) are associated with anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo-1) antibodies.

Prognosis: The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

 

Reference:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition

Chapter 53 Page nos. 53.5, 53.6 and 53.8

questions.text: A 40y multigravida presents at 12 weeks for a 1st trimester ultrasound evaluation. The nuchal translucency is measured as shown in the image. She subsequently undergoes a chorionic villous sampling and the fetal karyotype is normal. Her fetus still needs to be evaluated in the 2nd trimester for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cardiac defect

  • The image seen is the nuchal translucency (NT)
  • About NT:
  1. Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  2. Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  3. If NT increased, risk for 
  • Fetal aneuploidy
  • Various structural anomalies: Cardiac, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  1. Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)
  2. NT alone of used: 65% detection rate for Down Syndrome
  3. Combined test: NT + Dual marker (beta hCG + PAPP-A): 80% Detection rate
  4. NT > 3 mm/ > 99th percentile: Significant.

choices.text: Baby is crying because the diaper is wet
The quality of the mother’s feed is not good
Baby is getting only foremilk, the satiety value is missing
We should rule out neonatal sepsis

questions.text: A 3 days old baby’s mother came to the paediatric OPD. She is concerned that whenever she breast feeds her baby, her baby sleeps comfortably but after every 30 minutes the baby wakes up and starts crying. On further evaluation, you find that the mother has been breastfeeding the baby correctly, however the baby feeds for just 5-10 minutes after which he goes to sleep.  What could be the possible cause of frequent awakening in the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. baby is getting only foremilk, the satiety value is missing

We are focusing on the topic of fore milk & hind milk

  • The beginning part of the breast milk is the foremilk which contains all the protein, vitamin, minerals except fat.
  • The end part of the breast milk is known as hind milk which mainly rich in fat. It helps in the satiety value of the baby.
  • In the question, the baby is only getting the foremilk that’s why he is crying after every 30 minutes

Option A: if a baby’s diaper is wet, definitely baby will cry but the cause of cry in this question is fore milk hind milk imbalance

Option B: mother’s milk is the most nutritive milk for the baby

Option D: for neonatal sepsis baby should have fever or hypothermia with decreased feeding.

questions.text: Most common indication for liver transplantation in children is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Biliary atresia

Biliary atresia is a condition in which the normal extrahepatic biliary system is disrupted. Progressive damage of extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts secondary to inflammation may occur, leading to fibrosis, biliary cirrhosis, and eventual liver failure.

  • Biliary atresia is characterized by luminal obstruction of the extrahepatic bile duct with a fibrous ductal remnant representing the obliterated duct in the porta hepatis
  • The primary therapy is surgical.

“Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children, followed by metabolic and inborn disorders, autoimmune and familial cholestatic disorders, and acute hepatic necrosis.

Option A, B and D are not the most common cause of liver transplantation in children.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with itchy tense bulla over the limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. A clinical image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bullous pemphigoid

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous Pemphigoid: Elderly aged people are usually affected. It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.

It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils

DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction.

It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Chapter 50, Page no 50.10

questions.text: A farmer comes to skin OPD with painful, swollen foot which has discharging sinuses & dark grains coming out of sinuses. Gram stain was negative. Diagnosis of this case scenario would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eumycetoma

The diagnosis with the given case scenario would be Eumycetoma (Madura foot)

Clinical features: (GST)

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge

 

Treatment:

  1. Eumycetoma:
  • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  1. Actinomycetoma:
  • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
  • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Reference:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

questions.text: Which condition is most consistent with these fundus changes seen in a woman with headache and blurred vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension

  • This fundus examination reveals papilledema, characteristic of increased intracranial pressure of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri). In severe cases, ophthalmoplegia may occur. An elevation in cerebrospinal fluid opening pressure of greater than 250 mm H2O with normal cerebrospinal fluid composition and brain MRI without mass lesion confirm the diagnosis.
  • CSF leak presents with intracranial hypotension and unlikely to have papilledema
  • Diabetes Mellitus is associated with microaneurysms, dot/blot hemorrhages, cotton wool spots and neovascularization.

choices.text: Vaccines that contain toxoids may be administered during pregnancy
The hepatitis B vaccine series may be administered during pregnancy
Receiving the varicella vaccine is an indication for pregnancy termination
Conception should be delayed by 1 month after receiving the rubella vaccine

questions.text: All except which of the following are true regarding vaccinations in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Receiving the varicella vaccine is an indication for pregnancy termination

  • All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity
  • Live vaccines include: measles, mumps, rubella, varicella, HPV, HZV, varicella BCG, live attenuated influenza, oral polio, rota virus and oral typhoid.
  • Pregnancy should ideally be avoided for 1 month after receiving the vaccine.
  • But if a woman conceives after receiving the vaccine or while pregnant, it is not an indication for termination as the risk of congenital infection after the vaccine is very very low.
  • Toxoids and inactivated vaccines are safe in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 56 years old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking in shock with a BP of 70/50 mm Hg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 89%. Serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe acute pancreatitis 

The patient has a history of alcohol binge and clinical findings that suggest acute pancreatitis. The CT image shows non-enhancing pancreas. Further, renal failure, hypotension and hypoxemia suggest organ failure associated with severe acute pancreatitis

According to Modified Atlanta classification:

A. Mild acute pancreatitis:

(i) No organ failure

(ii) No local or systemic complications

B. Moderately severe acute pancreatitis:

(i) Organ failure that resolves within 48 h (transient organ failure) and/ or

(ii) Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

C. Severe acute pancreatitis: Persistent organ failure (>48 h)

(i) Single organ failure

(ii) Multiple organ failure.

questions.text: A 32y Primi delivered at 39 weeks by an emergency LSCS for deep transverse arrest. Following delivery of the baby, extension of the uterine incision was noted and sutured. Despite this the patient continued to bleed. The following procedure was done as shown. Which haemostatic surgical procedure is shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uterine Artery ligation

  • The image shown is ligation of the uterine artery
  • This is the 1st artery to be ligated during a stepwise devascularization surgery.

choices.text: Admit the patient to the ward and observe

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports a recent history of non-compliance with his prescribed proton pump inhibitor medication. On examination, he appears pale and has a rigid abdomen with rebound tenderness. CXR of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perform immediate exploratory laparotomy

Free air under the diaphragm on am erect chest X-ray is a hallmark sign of perforation. In this clinical scenario, the patient's history of peptic ulcer disease and recent non-compliance with medication suggest a possible perforated peptic ulcer. Given the patient's acute presentation and clinical examination findings of a rigid abdomen with rebound tenderness, immediate exploratory laparotomy is the next best step in management. This will allow for identification and repair of the perforation and possible removal of any contaminated tissue. Admitting the patient to the ward and observing would not be appropriate as this is a surgical emergency. Starting intravenous antibiotics and administering analgesia may provide some temporary relief but will not address the underlying issue of the perforation.

questions.text: Identify the following structure marked with asterisk:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Concha bullosa

  • Concha bullosa refers to the pneumatization of the middle turbinate. It is one of the most common variations of PNS anatomy.
  • Option C: Onodi air cell, is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell, important due to its proximity to the optic nerve and internal carotid artery
  • Option B: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, along the inferomedial orbital floor.

choices.text: Transformer mechanism is completely lost due to surgery

questions.text: Assuming a real ratio as 14:1 and lever ratio as 1.3:1, what would be the transformer ratio in a patient who has undergone tympanoplasty including ossiculoplasty with TORP (Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 14:1

TORP transmits vibrations on tympanic membrane to stapes footplate directly.

The transformer ratio can be calculated by multiplying the areal ratio by the lever ratio. In this case, 14 (areal ratio) x 1.3 (lever ratio) = 18 (transformer ratio). However, when a patient undergoes ossiculoplasty with a TORP, the lever ratio is lost because there are no ossicles. Therefore, only the areal ratio remains, and the transformer ratio would be 14:1. Option D is incorrect because although the lever ratio is lost, the transformer mechanism is not completely lost as the areal ratio still plays a role in sound transmission.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female consuming a vegetarian diet presented with tiredness & palpitations since a month. On blood examination, she had macrocytic RBCs with hypersegmented neutrophils. In the above patient, degenerative features will be seen in which part of the spinal cord as marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A > C

  • Given symptoms indicate Vitamin B12 deficiency & megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Given image is transverse section of spinal cord in which

A:  Dorsal white column

B:   Dorsal horn

C:  Lateral white column

D:   Anterior white column

  • Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord is a neurological complication of vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • It is characterized by degeneration of the dorsal column and the lateral column of the spinal cord due to demyelination.
  • Fasciculus Gracilis and cuneatus are dorsal column tracts in spinal cord.
  • In indicated image area A is showing dorsal column part in spinal cord. That’s why answer is A.

questions.text:
Find the true statements on Rinne tuning fork test?

  1. Positive means patient is having sensorineural hearing loss
  2. Negative means conductive deafness
  3. Bone conduction (BC) is more than air conduction in case of conductive loss
  4. Positive means there is no hearing loss
  5. Air conduction (AC) is more than bone conduction in case of conductive loss
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3, 4

The Rinne test is a commonly used clinical test to assess hearing loss. It compares bone conduction to air conduction of sound.

In a positive Rinne test, the patient can hear the sound when the vibrating tuning fork is held next to the external auditory canal (air conduction) for a longer time than when the tuning fork is placed on the mastoid bone behind the ear (bone conduction). This indicates that the patient has normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.

  • Positive Rinne test indicates AC>BC, normal, SNHL.

In a negative Rinne test, the patient cannot hear the sound when the vibrating tuning fork is held next to the external auditory canal (air conduction) for a longer time than when the tuning fork is placed on the mastoid bone behind the ear (bone conduction). This indicates that the patient has conductive hearing loss.

  • Negative Rinne test indicates BC>AC, CHL

It is important to note that the Rinne test is not always conclusive and should be used in conjunction with other clinical tests and patient history to accurately diagnose hearing loss.

choices.text: Kill areas of peripheral ischemic retina
Ablate peripheral blood vessels
Seal off leaking blood vessels

questions.text: A 32-year-old white man with a history of type-1 diabetes presents to you complaining of decreased vision. He has not seen an ophthalmologist in years. On examination, you find numerous areas of abnormal vasculature in the retina as shown in the picture below. Pan-retinal photocoagulation might be done in this patient to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kill areas of peripheral ischemic retina

PRP is performed to kill areas of peripheral ischemic retina.

By doing so, VEGF production is reduced, leading to cessation and regression of neovascularization.

While it is true that we sacrifice some of the peripheral retina with PRP, it is worth it to save important central vision.

questions.text: A 45-year old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar, nose & pinna pigmentation. Urine sample collected for benedicts test changes to black in the supernatant and the test gives greenish brown precipitate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alkaptonuria  

  • Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism resulting from homogentisic acid oxidase /dioxygenase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid (HA), an intermediate in the catabolism of tyrosine.
  • Manifestations includes homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing), arthritis, deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue.
  • Dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine will be helpful.

Incorrect answers:

False: Option A. Phenylketonuria: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase; C/F - mentally retardation, agitation, hyperactivity, tremors & convulsions due to interference of phenylalanine with neurotransmitter synthesis & hypopigmentation (inhibition of tyrosinase)

False: Option C. Tyrosinemia type-2: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase; C/F -Mental retardation, painful corneal lesions, photophobia and keratosis of palmar surface with increased urinary excretion of tyrosine and tyramine.

False: Option D. Argininosuccinic aciduria: Deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase with hyperammonemia and elevated argininosuccinate in CSF and excretion in urine and friable tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 304-305, Lippincott 7/e: P 274.

choices.text: Inspiratory reserve volume + Tidal volume + Expiratory reserve volume

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 millilitres).

questions.text: Identify the significance of the image shown below and what does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Death

  • The image shows Kevorkian sign (Trucking)
  • The Kevorkian sign or trucking is a postmortem phenomenon that occurs in the retinal vessels after death. It is named after Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who observed this phenomenon during his work as a pathologist.
  • After death, the blood pressure drops, causing the blood flow in the retinal vessels to break up into segments. This condition is called trucking, and it is considered an early sign of death. Trucking can occur all over the body, but it is easily seen in the retina by ophthalmoscopy.
  • The onset of trucking occurs within a few minutes of death and can persist for several hours. It is an important sign of death for forensic pathologists and medical examiners, as it helps to determine the time of death. It is important to note that trucking is not a definitive sign of death, and it can also occur in other conditions such as shock, severe hypothermia, or as a result of certain medications.

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 79

questions.text: Identify the structure that represents all 3 types of white matter?

Ans. D. D

  • B: is indicating translucent septa just below carpus callosum which acts as thin septa between 2 lateral ventricles known as septum pellucidum.
  • C:  is indicating the large mass of grey matter in diencephalon region known as thalamus.
  • D:  is indicating another band of white matter located just below to septum pellucidum known as fornix. Fornix is only structure in brain which is having all the 3 types of white matters.

questions.text: Following is not a part of ethmoid bone:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior turbinate

Inferior turbinate itself is a separate piece of bone. All other 3 are parts of ethmoid bone.

The ethmoid bone is located at the anterior part of the base of the skull, between the two orbits. It is a delicate, irregularly shaped bone that is made up of several smaller parts, including:

  1. Cribriform plate: This is a horizontal plate that forms the roof of the nasal cavity and contains several small foramina through which the olfactory nerves pass.
  2. Crista galli: This is a triangular process that projects upward from the cribriform plate and serves as an attachment site for the falx cerebri, a membrane that separates the two cerebral hemispheres.
  3. Perpendicular plate: This is a thin, vertical plate that extends inferiorly from the cribriform plate and forms the upper part of the nasal septum.
  4. Labyrinths: These are two delicate, scroll-shaped plates that form the lateral walls of the ethmoid bone and contain numerous small, air-filled cavities known as ethmoidal cells.
  5. Orbital plates: These are two thin, horizontally oriented plates that form the medial walls of the orbits and contribute to the formation of the medial wall of the anterior cranial fossa.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman has been diagnosed with stage IV melanoma and is scheduled to receive immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. The physician explains the mechanism of action and potential side effects of immune checkpoint inhibitors to the patient and her family. Which of the following is true about immune checkpoint inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nivolumab works by blocking the PD-1 receptor and is used to treat various types of cancer.

Among the given options, only nivolumab is an immune check point inhibitor whereas other drugs mentioned in the options act by other mechanisms.

  • Immune checkpoint inhibitors are a type of immunotherapy that work by releasing the brakes on the immune system, allowing it to attack cancer cells more effectively. Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks the PD-1 receptor on T cells, which prevents the inhibition of T cell activation and enhances the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. Nivolumab has been approved for the treatment of various types of cancer, including Hodgkin’s lymphoma, melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer, and kidney cancer.
  • Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF that inhibits angiogenesis, the formation of new blood vessels, and is used to treat solid tumors.
  • Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody against CD20 that depletes B cells and is used to treat lymphoma and autoimmune disorders.
  • Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor and is used to treat breast cancer.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence GATCTAC. What is the base sequence of RNA product?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. GUAGAUC

The base sequence of given DNA strand is 5’ GATCTAC 3’.

This sequence will be exactly same as the complementary or non-template strand of the DNA from which it is transcribed only difference will that U is replaced with T

So, the sequence of complementary DNA strand will be 5’ GTAGATC 3’. 

RNA formed from this template will have exactly same as the complementary or non-template strand of the DNA from which it is transcribed only difference will that U is replaced with T. So it will be

So, the sequence of mRNA strand will be 3’ CUAGAUG 5’ the direction is reversed as the two strands run antiparallel to each other.

By arranging this sequence in 5’ - 3’ direction, the answer we get is 5’ GUAGAUC 3’.

 

Reference: Harper 32/e: p 349

choices.text: Oxygen dissociation curve is shifted to right

questions.text: Fetal hemoglobin has higher affinity for oxygen due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreased 2, 3-DPG binding

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is a graph that shows the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) in the blood and the saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen (SO2). A right shift of the curve means that hemoglobin is less saturated with oxygen at any given PO2, while a left shift means that hemoglobin is more saturated with oxygen at any given PO2.

A right shift in the curve is caused by factors that promote the release of oxygen from hemoglobin, such as:

Increased PCO2, Increase Glycolysis

Increased acidity (decreased pH), increase in H+ ion

Increased temperature

Increased 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG)

All of these factors cause hemoglobin to have a lower affinity for oxygen, which means that it releases oxygen more readily to the tissues.

 

A left shift in the curve is caused by factors that promote the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin, such as:

Decreased PCO2,

Decreased acidity (increased pH)

Decreased temperature – blood bank

Decreased 2,3-DPG

All of these factors cause hemoglobin to have a higher affinity for oxygen, which means that it binds oxygen more readily and does not release it as easily to the tissues.

questions.text: A 7 months old baby was diagnosed with urea cycle disorder. Past H/O same disease in the previous baby and died at 1-year of age. Now, what could be the rationale for feeding benzoic acids to subjects with a urea cycle enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid   

  • In urea cycle disorder, amino nitrogen is eliminated in other forms.
  • e.g. as hippuric acid (Benzoyl conjugate of glycine) or phenyl acetyl glutamine.
  • SODIUM BENZOATE (benzoic acid) + Co A → Benzoyl co A + glycine (LIVER) → Benzoyl glycine (HIPPURIC ACID) → excreted in urine
  • 1 mole of Benzoic acid → removes → 1 mole of NH3 as glycine
  • SODUM PHENYL ACETATE + Co A → SODUM PHENYL ACETYL Co A + glutamine → SODUM PHENYL ACETYL glutamine → urine
  • 1 mole of PHENYL ACETATE → removes → 2 mole of NH3 as glutamine

Incorrect answers:

False: Option (b), Option (c) and Option (d) are all incorrect.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: page 206.

questions.text: Identify the type of air cell shown in the picture (marked with white arrow):
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Haller cells

  1. Haller cells are anterior ethmoid air cells that are located between the maxillary sinus and the orbit (floor of orbit). They are also called infraorbital ethmoid cells and are named after the Swiss anatomist, Albrecht von Haller.
  2. Agger nasi cells are small anterior ethmoid air cells that are located above the frontonasal duct. These cells are present on both sides of the nose and are named after the Latin word "agger" which means "mound" or "heap".
  3. Onodi cells are posterior ethmoid air cells that are located at the roof of the sphenoid sinus (near to optic nerve). They are also called sphenoethmoidal cells or posterior ethmoidal cells. These cells are named after the Hungarian ophthalmologist, Miklos Onodi.
  4. Concha bullosa is an ethmoid air cell that is present within the middle turbinate. It is a pneumatized variant of the middle turbinate and is caused by the expansion of an ethmoid air cell into the turbinate. Concha bullosa can be unilateral or bilateral and can cause obstruction of the nasal cavity.

choices.text: Sildenafil works by blocking alpha receptors in the penile tissue, leading to vasodilation and increased blood flow to the penis
Sildenafil works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), leading to increased levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) and smooth muscle relaxation in the penile tissue
Sildenafil works by blocking the action of testosterone, leading to decreased libido and improved erectile function
Sildenafil works by stimulating the production of nitric oxide, leading to increased blood flow to the penis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his physician with complaints of erectile dysfunction. The physician prescribes sildenafil, a medication commonly used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. The physician explains to the patient that sildenafil works by inhibiting an enzyme in the body. Which of the following statements best describes the mechanism of action of sildenafil?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sildenafil works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), leading to increased levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) and smooth muscle relaxation in the penile tissue

  • While alpha receptor blockers may be used for the treatment of hypertension or benign prostatic hyperplasia, they are not commonly used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Alpha blockers would lead to vasodilation and increased blood flow throughout the body, not just to the penis.
  • This is the most accurate statement. Sildenafil works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), an enzyme that breaks down cGMP in the penile tissue. By inhibiting PDE5, sildenafil increases the levels of cGMP, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow to the penis, resulting in improved erectile function.
  • Testosterone is a hormone involved in the regulation of libido and sexual function, but it is not the primary target of sildenafil. Blocking the action of testosterone would not improve erectile function.
  • Nitric oxide is a molecule that plays a role in vasodilation and blood flow regulation, but it is not the primary target of sildenafil. While sildenafil may indirectly increase the production of nitric oxide through the inhibition of PDE5, it does not directly stimulate its production.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match with respect to the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sparsentan - Dual endothelin and angiotensin receptor antagonist used for the treatment of CHF

  • Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks by blocking the binding of CGRP to its receptors.
  • Sparsentan is a dual endothelin as well as angiotensin receptor antagonist used for the treatment of IgA nephrotpathy.
  • Lenacapavir is an HIV-1 capsid inhibitor used for the treatment of HIV infection by preventing the formation of functional HIV-1 capsids, which are necessary for the replication of the virus.
  • Teplizumab is an anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody used for the prevention of type 1 diabetes in high-risk individuals by modulating the immune response that attacks insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.

Important New Drugs

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with chronic hypertension is prescribed a new medication by her physician. The medication is available in two forms, an oral tablet and an intravenous (IV) injection. The physician explains to the patient that the IV injection has 100% bioavailability, while the oral tablet has a bioavailability of only 60%. The patient is concerned about the cost of the medication and asks if the oral tablet can be used instead of the IV injection. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the use of the oral tablet versus the IV injection in terms of bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The oral tablet should be used instead of the IV injection because it is less expensive and has adequate bioavailability

  • Although the IV injection has 100% bioavailability, it is generally reserved for situations where rapid onset of action is needed or when the patient cannot tolerate oral medication. In this case, the oral tablet has a bioavailability of 60%, which is considered adequate for most medications. Therefore, the IV injection may not be necessary and the oral tablet can be used instead.
  • This is the most accurate statement. The oral tablet should be used instead of the IV injection because it is less expensive and has adequate bioavailability. The fact that the oral tablet has a lower bioavailability does not necessarily mean that it is less effective or less desirable for the patient. In this case, the oral tablet may be a better choice due to cost considerations.
  • While safety and tolerability are important factors to consider when selecting a medication, the bioavailability of the medication is also an important consideration. The fact that the oral tablet has a lower bioavailability does not necessarily mean that it is safer or better tolerated.

While the IV injection may have a more rapid onset of action, it does not necessarily mean that it is more effective in lowering blood pressure. The oral tablet may still be an effective option even with a lower bioavailability.

choices.text: Inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and decreases production of thromboxane A2, thereby reducing platelet activation and aggregation

Inhibits the formation of fibrin by blocking the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevation. The patient is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The cardiologist orders the patient to take an antiplatelet drug after the procedure to prevent further clot formation. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of aspirin, a commonly used antiplatelet drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and decreases production of thromboxane A2, thereby reducing platelet activation and aggregation

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which is responsible for the production of thromboxane A2, a potent platelet activator and aggregator. By decreasing the production of thromboxane A2, aspirin reduces the activation and aggregation of platelets, thereby preventing further clot formation. Aspirin is commonly used as an antiplatelet drug for the prevention of cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction and stroke.
  • Option B describes the mechanism of action of P2Y12 receptor inhibitors, such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor. These drugs inhibit the activation and aggregation of platelets by blocking the P2Y12 receptor on the platelet surface.
  • Option C describes the mechanism of action of anticoagulants, such as heparin and warfarin. These drugs inhibit the formation of fibrin by blocking the coagulation cascade and the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.
  • Option D describes the mechanism of action of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor inhibitors, such as abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban. These drugs bind to glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors on the surface of activated platelets, preventing the aggregation of platelets.

To promote diuresis and increase renal blood flow
To increase the excretion of unbound salicylate
To counteract the acidosis caused by salicylate poisoning

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the emergency department after intentionally overdosing on aspirin. She reports taking approximately 30 tablets (325 mg each) over the past 12 hours. On examination, the patient is tachypneic with hyperventilation and has a metabolic acidosis. The emergency department physician orders aggressive hydration and urine alkalinization. Which of the following is the primary reason for the use of urine alkalinization in aspirin poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. To increase urinary excretion of salicylate

  • Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is commonly used as an analgesic and antipyretic. However, in overdose, aspirin can cause toxicity due to its effect on the respiratory center, leading to hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis, and metabolic acidosis. Urine alkalinization is a commonly used treatment for acidic drug poisoning like aspirin poisoning to increase the urinary excretion of salicylate, the active ingredient in aspirin.
  • By alkalinizing the urine, the ionization of salicylate is increased, leading to increased excretion of the drug in the urine. This is because the ionized form of salicylate is more soluble and can be excreted more easily than the non-ionized form. Urine alkalinization can be achieved by administering intravenous sodium bicarbonate, which increases the pH of the urine.
  • Option B is incorrect because urine alkalinization does not promote diuresis or increase renal blood flow. However, aggressive hydration is often used in the treatment of aspirin poisoning to maintain adequate renal perfusion and promote urinary excretion of salicylate.
  • Option C is incorrect because urine alkalinization primarily increases the excretion of ionized salicylate, not unbound salicylate.
  • Option D is incorrect because sodium bicarbonate directly counteracts the acidosis caused by salicylate poisoning and not by urinary alkalinization.

questions.solution:
Ans. B. Familial Hypercholesterolemia  

  • The deposition of lipids in subcutaneous tissue leads to xanthomas.
  • Xanthelasma are lipid deposits under the periorbital skin and contain mainly cholesterol.
  • Tendinous xanthoma are found over the tendons.
  • Deposits of lipids in cornea lead to corneal arcus; indicating hypercholesterolemia

Incorrect answers:

FALSE: Option A. Familial Chylomicronemia: C/F- Hepatomegaly, eruptive xanthoma and abdominal pain.

FALSE: Option C. Abetalipoproteinemia: Low levels of serum triglycerides, cholesterol and phospholipids. C/F- Blindness dut to degenerative changes in retina and spiny projections in erythrocytes (acanthocytes).

FALSE: Option D. Broad Beta Disease: Palmar xanthoma and increased risk for vascular disease.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: P245, 246.

questions.text: All are true about congenital toxoplasmosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Macrocephaly

Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii transmitted from mother to the fetus during pregnancy. The findings of congenital toxoplasmosis include:

  1. Chorioretinitis: inflammation and scarring of the retina and choroid, which can lead to vision impairment or blindness.
  2. Hydrocephalus: accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain, which can cause an increase in head size.
  3. Intracranial calcifications: deposits of calcium in the brain, which can be seen on imaging studies and may cause neurological problems.
  4. Jaundice: yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood.
  5. Hepatosplenomegaly: enlargement of the liver and spleen due to infection and inflammation.
  6. Skin rash: a non-itchy, maculopapular rash may be present.
  7. Lymphadenopathy: swelling of the lymph nodes.
  8. Feeding difficulties, respiratory distress, seizures, and developmental delays may also be present.

Not all infants with congenital toxoplasmosis will exhibit all of these findings, and the severity of the infection can vary depending on factors such as gestational age at the time of infection and the mother's immune status.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient underwent an open Lichtenstein hernioplasty for inguinal hernia repair. Postoperatively, the patient complained of persistent pain at the surgical site, which worsened with physical activity. On examination, the surgical wound appeared well-healed, and there was no sign of infection. The patient was diagnosed with chronic pain syndrome. The patient was advised to take pain medication and to avoid strenuous physical activity. Physical therapy and nerve blocks were also recommended to manage the pain. The patient's symptoms improved gradually over time, and he was able to return to his normal activities after several weeks. Which of the following is the most common complication of inguinal hernia repair surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chronic pain

Option A: Wound infection is a common complication after hernia surgery. It can be managed with antibiotics and wound care, including frequent dressing changes and cleansing. In severe cases, wound debridement and reoperation may be necessary.

Option B: Seroma formation is a collection of fluid that accumulates under the skin at the surgical site. It can be managed conservatively with observation or drained using needle aspiration or open drainage.

Option C: Hematoma can be managed with observation or drained using needle aspiration or open drainage. In severe cases, surgical exploration may be necessary.

Option D: Chronic pain. The most common complication of inguinal hernia repair surgery is actually chronic pain, with an incidence rate of up to 30% due to nerve injury, mesh related pain. It can result in chronic pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected area. It can be managed with pain medication and physical therapy. In severe cases, surgical exploration or nerve repair may be necessary.

questions.text: A young female presents with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family gives history of abnormal behavior. Based on clinical features, which of the following will be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

Clinical features are highly suggestive of (Primary) hyperparathyroidism.

This patient has some of the classic features described in the literature –

  • Abdominal groans
  • Psychic moans
  • Renal stones (though not present in the question)

This patient also has bone pain which is again suggestive of hyperparathyroidism in this clinical setting.

As such – THE MOST COMMON CAUSE OF PRIMARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM IS PARATHYROID ADENOMA >> HYPERPLASIA.

Tc99m Sestamibi is the nuclear imaging modality utilized for the diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. The patient reports completing a course of chemotherapy that included doxorubicin. The patient now reports experiencing shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. Echocardiography reveals a reduced ejection fraction of 40%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cardiomyopathy

  • Doxorubicin is an anticancer drug that is commonly used in the treatment of breast cancer.
  • Anthracyclines like doxorubicin have cardiotoxic potential which can present as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.
  • Cardiomyopathy is characterized by damage to the heart muscle, leading to a reduced ejection fraction and symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations.
  • Option A describes the adverse effect of pulmonary embolism, which is a blood clot in the lung that can cause similar symptoms to cardiomyopathy, but it is not typically associated with doxorubicin use.

 

  • Option C describes the adverse effect of pulmonary fibrosis which is caused by drugs like bleomycin and busulfan.
  • Option D describes the adverse effect of hemolytic anemia, which is characterized by the destruction of red blood cells and is not typically associated with doxorubicin use.

choices.text: Surgical intervention, including bile duct repair or reconstruction

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallbladder removal. Postoperatively, the patient developed symptoms of abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice. Imaging studies revealed a proximal bile duct injury. Imaging studies revealed cystic duct leak. What is the appropriate management of a patient of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ERCP with stenting

The appropriate management for a patient who has suffered a cystic duct leak post-cholecystectomy is ERCP with stenting.

Option A: Observation and supportive care alone are not appropriate for the management of bile duct injury post-cholecystectomy, as this can lead to serious complications, including biliary peritonitis and sepsis.

Option B: ERCP with stenting or balloon dilatation is a minimally invasive approach that can be used to manage cystic duct leak and partial bile duct injury. This technique allows for a temporary diversion of bile flow, and the injured bile duct can often heal over time.

Option C: Surgical intervention is the mainstay of treatment for proximal or central bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy. This may involve a hepaticojejunostomy, which is the creation of a new connection between the injured bile duct and the small intestine, or a biliary enteric anastomosis. In severe cases, a liver transplant may be necessary.

Option D: Corticosteroid therapy is not appropriate for the management of bile duct injury post-cholecystectomy. It has no role in the treatment of biliary injury and can lead to serious side effects.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is diagnosed with enterococcal endocarditis. She has no known drug allergies. Which of the following would reflect standard therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ampicillin

If sensitive – ampicillin plus gentamicin (aminoglycoside added for synergy) is the standard therapy in patients with enterococcal IE.

In case of high level resistance to penicillin and gentamicin – can opt for vancomycin. In case of VRE (vancomycin resistant enterococcus) – can opt for Daptomycin or Linezolid (tigecycline is effective for complicated intra-abdominal or skin/structure infections but less effective in bacteremia and IE).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, dizziness, and increased urination. The patient reports taking oral anti-diabetic medications, including metformin, sulfonylureas, and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely associated with metformin use?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lactic acidosis

  • Metformin is an oral anti-diabetic medication that is commonly used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. While metformin is effective in reducing blood glucose levels, it can also cause adverse effects, including lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis is a rare but serious complication that can occur due to accumulation of lactic acid in the blood.
  • Sulfonylureas are another class of oral anti-diabetic medications that work by stimulating insulin secretion from the pancreas. Hypoglycemia is a common adverse effect of sulfonylurea use, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, and increased urination.
  • DPP-4 inhibitors are a newer class of oral anti-diabetic medications that work by increasing the levels of incretin hormones, which stimulate insulin secretion and inhibit glucagon secretion. DPP-4 inhibitors are generally well-tolerated, with few adverse effects. Most common adverse effect of DPP-4 inhibitors is nasopharyngitis. It may also cause pancreatitis.
  • Option B describes the adverse effect of weight gain, which is a potential adverse effect of some oral anti-diabetic medications, such as sulfonylureas and thiazolidinediones.
  • Option D describes the adverse effect of pancreatitis, which is a potential adverse effect of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists.

questions.text: A 39-year-old G4P3 presents at 6 weeks pregnancy with lower abdominal pain. A TVS is performed. What findings would be expected on TVS if her dates are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gestational sac, yolk sac, fetal pole with cardiac activity

On TVS:

  • Gestational sac appears at 5 weeks
  • Yolk sac appears at 5.5 weeks
  • Fetal pole with cardiac activity at 6 weeks
  • On Trans-abdominal scan, all these appear 1 week later.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the ED with a pulsating headache and dizziness. She has been non-compliant with her blood pressure medications over the past month. She usually takes Enalapril and metoprolol. BP is 245/120 mmHg and heart rate is 88 beats per minute. She has cotton wool spots on fundus exam. What is the best treatment option among the choices listed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Labetalol

Labetalol is the most effective agent for most hypertensive emergencies. It has broad applications for this indication due to its β-blocking and selective α-blocking effects

A hypertensive emergency is defined by BP ≥180/120 mmHg and signs of end-organ damage. This patient has signs of hypertensive retinopathy.

Other signs of end-organ damage include acute changes in mental status, acute renal failure as shown by elevated BUN or oliguria, ischemic changes on EKG.

Causes of hypertensive emergency include

  1. Aortic dissection
  2. Acute pulmonary edema
  3. Eclampsia and pre-eclampsia
  4. Sympathetic crisis (pheochromocytoma or cocaine toxicity)
  5. Neurologic emergencies (SAH, ischemic stroke)

Nitroglycerin is a potent venodilator and a better choice for hypertensive emergencies due to ACS because it decreases preload and cardiac output.

Phentolamine is an α and α adrenergic blocker. It is effective in hypertensive emergencies due to a sympathetic crisis (like pheochromocytoma)

Clonidine is a central α agonist and has a unique indication for patients who have stopped taking this drug and experience rebound hypertension.

  • SD (s) calculation: = √Variance = √Σ (x – x)2/n

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of right lower leg pain for 3 months after a fall down a flight of stairs. On physical examination, he was febrile. X-ray of the limb revealed a mass involving the right tibial diaphysis, with expansion and destruction of the overlying cortex. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and the microscopic appearance is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ewing sarcoma

The image shows small round blue tumor cells and coupled with the history (child, fever and diaphysial lesion), the diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma is easier.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with a history of tuberculosis presents to the clinic with complaints of cough, fever, and night sweats. The patient reports completing a course of anti-tuberculosis medications but reports recurrent symptoms. Sputum culture reveals that the mycobacterium is resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin and levofloxacin and sensitive to other first line drugs and linezolide as well as bed aquiline. Which type of tuberculosis it can be referred to as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pre-XDR Tuberculosis

  • The patient's history and sputum culture indicate that the mycobacterium is resistant to isoniazid, rifampicin and levofloxacin, but is sensitive to other first-line drugs and linezolide, as well as bedaquiline. Based on this information, the patient's condition can be referred to as Pre-XDR Tuberculosis
