choices.text: NAC prevents renal toxicity by detoxifying NAPQI and decreasing NAPQI production
Nearly 30% of patients treated with IV NAC will develop anaphylactoid reactions
NAC crosses the placenta but is safe in pregnancy
PO NAC is superior to IV NAC in patients presenting within 8-24 hours

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with abdominal pain and vomiting approximately 5 hours of ingestion of 8g paracetamol in an apparent suicide attempt. When considering NAC in this patient, which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. NAC crosses the placenta but is safe in pregnancy

The principal therapy for acetaminophen toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which serves as a glutathione precursor and a sulfur-containing glutathione substitute. It helps prevent hepatotoxicity by detoxifying NAPQI and decreasing NAPQI production. Approximately 2-6% of patients treated with IV NAC will develop anaphylactoid reactions.

The majority of symptoms are mild and consist of transient skin rashes and flushing.

Treating the mother with NAC is safe and effective, and NAC effectively crosses the placenta. Both PO and IV NAC are equally effective in treating patients who present 8-24 hours after ingestion, although the overall rate of liver injury is significantly higher in this group.

Anaphylactoid reactions are much less frequent with PO NAC; however, up to 50% of patients receiving oral NAC usually omit.

Antiemetics are advisable prior to PO NAC dosing, but there is little data about the effectiveness of this approach.

choices.text: Incision and drainage under general anesthesia

questions.text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. USG revealed abscess cavity of 40 cc volume and 4 cm in diameter. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Suction catheter drainage

The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to carry on breastfeeding.

“In abscesses >3 cm in diameter or those containing more than 30 mL of pus (assessed on ultrasonography), a vacuum suction catheter is inserted under ultrasound guidance to drain the pus (Figure 58.24 and 58.5). The patient should be reviewed on alternate days by clinical examination and ultrasonography. Any residual collection should be aspirated. The antibiotics are modifed according to the microbiological culture report. In patients with a suction drain, the catheter is irrigated with cold normal saline (cold to reduce pain) on each visit until complete resolution. Antibiotics should be continued for 14 days.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of cirrhosis of the liver presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. The preferred diuretic for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eplerenone

 

  • Cirrhosis of the liver can lead to portal hypertension, which can result in the accumulation of fluid in the abdomen (ascites) and swelling of the lower limbs (edema). Diuretics are commonly used to treat these symptoms.
  • Eplerenone is a selective aldosterone receptor antagonist that is commonly used to treat hypertension and heart failure. It is also a preferred diuretic for the treatment of cirrhotic ascites due to its aldosterone receptor antagonism, which helps to decrease sodium and water retention.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Triamterene: is a potassium-sparing diuretic that is often used in combination with other diuretics. It is not typically used as a first-line agent for cirrhotic ascites.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: is a thiazide-like diuretic that is often used to treat hypertension. While it may be effective for mild cases of edema, it is typically not sufficient for the treatment of cirrhotic ascites.

 

Option D. Furosemide, is a loop diuretic that is often used for the treatment of cirrhotic ascites. However, it is not the preferred diuretic due to its potential to cause electrolyte imbalances and renal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to AIIMS emergency after an RTA. His BP is 90/70 with a HR of 114/min. FAST exam is positive and massive transfusion protocol is initiated. Which of the following is not a likely adverse effect of the protocol?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypercalcemia

In blood banks - citrate is used as an anticoagulant.

If transfusion is too fast or the patient has liver dysfunction, then there is a risk of overwhelming the body with citrate that can bind calcium, causing hypocalcemia

Citrate will be metabolized by the liver into HCO3, which may lead to a metabolic alkalosis. However, if blood is infused rapidly or there is liver dysfunction, then metabolism is overwhelmed and is not sufficient. In this case citrate itself can cause a metabolic acidosis (typically a HAGMA)

Hypokalemia may seem an ambiguous choice but as red cells begin active metabolism, potassium is actively taken up by these cells and may result in hypokalemia (Note that old PRBCs can result in hyperkalemia especially in patients with renal failure and in neonates)

If blood products are not warmed, it may lower the body temperature, causing hypothermia. Hypothermia may cause worsening coagulopathy as well.

questions.text: With anterior peritoneal cavity entry during vaginal hysterectomy, the final layer incised to gain entry is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vesicouterine fold

  • The vesicouterine fold is the final layer to gain entry into the peritoneal cavity during a vaginal hysterectomy (VH)
  • During a VH, after giving a circumferential incision on the cervix, anteriorly, the bladder is separated from the underlying cervix. After separating, the UV fold of peritoneum is incised and the peritoneal cavity is entered.
  • Posteriorly, the post vaginal wall is separated from the posterior cervix and the Pouch of Douglas is entered by incising the peritoneum.

choices.text: Severe mitral regurgitation with papillary muscle dysfunction

questions.text: A 63-year woman old presents to the AIIMS emergency chest pain after an RTA. Which resulted in crushed left lower limb. ECG shows 1-2 mm ST elevations in leads V2-V4 & troponin are elevated. The patient undergoes CAG which was normal. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Akinetic LV apex with ballooning

This patient demonstrates the classic presentation of stress-induced cardiomyopathy, also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This incompletely understood STEMI mimic typically follows severe emotional or physiological stress and may be due to an anatomic predisposition to ischemia in states of extreme catecholaminergic tone. The typical patient is a post-menopausal woman with ECG changes, including ST-elevations or pronounced T-wave inversions. CAG is required to make the diagnosis through an absence of significant coronary disease on angiography and akinesis of the LV apex (apical ballooning), typically in a non-coronary distribution.

The clinical features and temporal events do not suggest a diagnosis of Aortic Dissection.

Ramus intermedius is a normal coronary anatomic variant involving a trifurcation of the left main coronary artery, with the ramus intermedius arising between the LAD and left circumflex. It is present in roughly 20% of individuals.

Severe MR would not typically cause any of these major findings.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman was on MF but could not achieve glycemic control. She has had a previous osteoporotic fracture and has a history of recurrent UTIs. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Semaglutide

Since the patient is morbidly obese – she can benefit from the use of oral Semaglutide. Pioglitazone can cause osteoporosis and weight gain – and hence not an appropriate choice in this patient. Since the patient does not want to take injections – insulin is not likely an option (even-though one can consider inhaled insulin like afrezza – still it is associated with weight gain and afrezza is not available in India as of now). Recurrent UTIs is one of the strongest contraindications for the use of SGLT2 inhibitors.

choices.text: Reactionary hemorrhage occurs 24-48 hours after surgery
Reactionary hemorrhage is responsible for post thyroidectomy airway obstruction
Secondary hemorrhage occurs 7-14 days after surgery
Secondary hemorrhage occurs due to erosion by surgical drain tube

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about surgical hemorrhage:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reactionary hemorrhage occurs 24-48 hours after surgery

  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours after surgery
  • It occurs due to slippage of ligature or rise in BP after surgery leading to clot dislodgement.
  • After total thyroidectomy, slippage of ligature of STA or ITA may lead to hematoma in thyroidectomy field, leading to tracheal compression.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is a delayed hemorrhage due to erosion of vessels by infection, drain/pressure, tumor.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with gram negative sepsis from urinary tract infection and started on IV Piperacillin-Tazobactum. She had normal renal function on presentation but on day 7, she developed acute renal failure with rising creatinine. Urine testing revealed eosinophiluria. Which of the following will the gold standard test for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Kidney biopsy

AIN diagnostic Tools:

A. Clinical Suspicion ® fever, Rash with AKI

B. Blood Tests: AKI, Eosinophilia, Elevated ESR, Transaminases

C. Urine tests: Eosinophiluria, WBC casts

D. Kidney Biopsy: Gold standard to diagnose AIN

Renal ultrasound or CT scan – Large swollen kidney, increased echogenicity (U/S) – Not specific, useful to exclude other AKI causes.

Renal gallium scan- Based on gallium binding to lactoferrin on WBCs – Not sensitive or specific for AIN (once an overhyped investigation).

questions.text: A woman comes in for an annual gynecologic examination. During speculum examination, you see the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Perform a cervical biopsy

  • When a cervical growth is seen, a biopsy HAS to be taken
  • Biopsy is taken using punch biopsy forceps
  • Pap smear is a screening method; it is done when there is no growth.

choices.text: Bronchiolitis Obliterans Organizing Pneumonia (BOOP)

questions.text: A 43-year-old gentleman presented with 5 weeks of progressive dyspnoea and intermittent fever. Blood reports – TLC: 18000, CRP & ESR elevated, CXR shows bilateral areas of consolidation. You started him on empirical antibiotics and the patient is not responding and repeat CXR revealed new areas of consolidation. The most likely diagnosis is that is to be confirmed is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bronchiolitis Obliterans Organizing Pneumonia (BOOP)

This case is a typical presentation for BOOP. The patients usually would have been diagnosed as Community Acquired pneumonia for a long time and would have had multiple antibiotic courses before the diagnosis is reached. Lung biopsy is the definitive investigation and will reveal organising pneumonia without any organisms and cultures of the specimens would be negative.

Coming to the other options - ABPA presents on the background of gradually worsening asthma which is resistant to therapy. The patient neither has background asthma nor a wheeze to substantiate ABPA and hence ruled out. The duration of symptoms (too short) and chest x-ray findings would be unusual for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Goodpasture syndrome could present in this fashion, but in the absence of hemoptysis and renal involvement- diagnosis is less likely.

questions.text: Which muscle is known as the ‘Key muscle of the gluteal region’?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Piriformis

  • It is difficult to identify the structures during dissection of gluteal region.
  • Once we identify the pyriformis then it becomes very easy to identify nearby structures. Hence it is known as “Key muscle of gluteal region.”

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia was recently started on an antipsychotic medication. Over the past week, the patient has been experiencing symptoms of restlessness, including difficulty sitting still, pacing, and a strong urge to move his legs. Which of the following medications should be added to the treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propranolol

 

Explanation: The patient's symptoms are suggestive of akathisia, a common side effect of antipsychotic medications. Akathisia is characterized by a subjective sense of restlessness, and objective signs of restlessness such as the inability to sit still, and pacing around.

 

A. Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is considered the DOC for managing akathisia.

 

B. Lorazepam can be used for managing akathisia but is not its first line treatment.

 

C. Benztropine is an anticholinergic agent used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), such as dystonia and drug induced parkinsonism, which can also be side effects of antipsychotic medications. However, it is not effective for treating akathisia.

 

D. Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that can be used to treat mild EPS, like drug-induced parkinsonism, but it is not the preferred choice for managing akathisia.

choices.text: IV, II, III, I
III, IV, II, I

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of Gram staining:

I. Diluted carbol fuschin

II. Acetone alcohol

III. Crystal violet

IV. Mordant
questions.solution:
Ans. D. III, IV, II, I

Gram staining procedure:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his chest. He had been lifting heavy objects and moving around a lot that day. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pneumothorax

The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the right lung points to a diagnosis of right sided pneumothorax. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax may be seen in a patient with Marfanoid habitus.

choices.text: Paralytic ileus- Put a NG tube

questions.text: Three years following open appendicectomy, 28/male presented with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. Abdomen showed hyper-peristalsis. X ray abdomen showed the following. What is the likely pathology and the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adhesive obstruction- CECT abdomen

Adhesive obstruction is the MC complication (late) of appendicectomy. X ray shows mechanical obstruction- step ladder pattern of air fluid levels. Next step in mechanical obstruction is CECT abdomen to identify aetiology/site of obstruction and presence of bowel ischemia.

Causes of adhesions:

  • Acute inflammation: Sites of anastomoses, peritonealisation of raw areas, trauma, ischaemia
  • Foreign material: Talc, starch, gauze, silk
  • Infection: Peritonitis, tuberculosis
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions: Crohn’s disease
  • Radiation enteritis

Management:

  • Initial management is based on intravenous rehydration and nasogastric decompression; occasionally, this treatment is curative. Although an initial conservative regimen is considered appropriate, regular assessment is mandatory to ensure that strangulation does not occur. Conservative treatment should not usually be prolonged beyond 72 hours.
  • When laparotomy is required, although multiple adhesions may be found, only one may be causative. If there is absolute certainty that this is the cause of the obstruction, this should be divided and the remaining adhesions can be left in situ unless severe angulation is present.

choices.text: Recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation
Rotator cuff tear

questions.text: Bankart’s lesion is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation

Lesions Associated with Recurrent Dislocation:

In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations. In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.

In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears not only the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, but also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula. This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion. Most authors agree that the Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

A humeral head impaction fracture can be produced as the shoulder is dislocated anteriorly, and the humeral head is impacted against the rim of the glenoid at the time of dislocation. This Hill-Sachs lesion is a defect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with warfarin induced bleeding receives IV vitamin K, 4 U PRBCs and 4U FFP. 4h later, she begins to complain of shortness of breath. Vitals T - 39°C, RR 35/min, SpO2 84% on RA, and BP 88/52 mm Hg. Exam revealed B/L crackles and the patient was intubated for respiratory failure. CXR is as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. TRALI

Anaphylaxis presents with urticaria/Angioedema +/- shock/bronchospasm/laryngeal edema. Fever is uncommon.

TACO is a circulatory overload state and it is not associated with fever since it is NOT an immune reaction. BP generally tends to be normal/increased and responds to diuretics

It is unlikely that aspiration could have causes such a dramatic deterioration and it is unlikely in a patient without a history of low GCS or coma

This is a classic TRALI – occurs < 6h of transfusion of blood products & usually associated with fever/hypotension and respiratory failure. Note that TRALI is the MCC of transfusion related death.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is evaluated for sudden paralysis of the right side. MRI is as shown below. Identify the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute ischemic stroke

The most likely diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke. The diffusion-weighted MRIs shown (top) exhibit a small area of acute infarction and/or cytotoxic edema in the left hemisphere, whereas the perfusion-weighted MRIs shown (bottom) depict a much larger area of impaired cerebral perfusion in the left hemisphere. The difference between these two areas is believed to approximate the ischemic penumbra, or the territory of brain that is abnormal but still viable at the time MRI is performed.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with ESRD due to IgA nephropathy received deceased donor kidney transplant two weeks ago. Her HLA mismatch was 6 out of 6, she had low level HLA type I donor specific antibodies (DSA) but cross match was negative. She received Basiliximab for the induction. She underwent an allograft kidney biopsy due to high creatinine. Biopsy and C4d staining is shown below. What should be the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Start IVIG + steroid + Plasmapheresis ± Rituximab

The biopsy features with glomerulitis, peritubular capillaritis and c4d positivity are consistent with antibody mediated rejections (AMR). Treatment of acute AMR immediate post-transplant is with Plasmapheresis + IVIG + steroid ± Rituximab. There were risk factors for AMR with pre-formed DSA, basiliximab induction and high degree of HLA mismatch.

Obtaining DSA would be second best choice, but wouldn’t wait to get DSA report before starting treatment.

BK nephropathy usually causes tubulitis, not glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis.

Thymoglobulin and steroid is used for the treatment of cellular rejections.

choices.text: Mixed respiratory acidosis and respiratory alkalosis
Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

questions.text: 40-year-old gentleman came with complaints for diarrhea since three days. His blood gas analysis shows the following findings pH- 7.14, Hco3- 9 pCo2- 30. Your inference is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

Stepwise approach to Acid base disorders will help.

Step 1 – Find out the primary disorder.

Look for the pH. 7.14 indicates acidosis. And this easily correlates with the low HCO3- and hence the primary disorder is metabolic acidosis.

Step 2 – Find out the Compensation.

Expected PaCo2 in metabolic acidosis by Winter’s formula = (1.5 x S.HCO3 + 8). Here expected change in pCO2 = (1.5 x 9) + 8 = 21 (+/- 2) = 19-23

Patient’s PaCo2 is way more than expected and hence there is an additional component of respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female develops eye pain and reduced visual acuity. Which of the following is not considered as a treatment option thyroid eye disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rituximab

Management of Thyroid eye disease -

Mild to moderate: Conservative (Selenium 100mg BID can be tried)

Severe disease: Glucocorticoids, orbital decompression, orbital radiotherapy & teprotumumab (IGF1R mAb approved by FDA in 2020).

choices.text: Reactionary hemorrhage occurs 24-48 hours after surgery
Reactionary hemorrhage is responsible for post thyroidectomy airway obstruction
Secondary hemorrhage occurs 7-14 days after surgery
Secondary hemorrhage occurs due to erosion by surgical drain tube

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about surgical hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reactionary hemorrhage occurs 24-48 hours after surgery

  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours after surgery
  • It occurs due to slippage of ligature or rise in BP after surgery leading to clot dislodgement.
  • After total thyroidectomy, slippage of ligature of STA or ITA may lead to hematoma in thyroidectomy field, leading to tracheal compression.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is a delayed hemorrhage due to erosion of vessels by infection, drain/pressure, tumor.

choices.text: Flex the distal phalanx of the thumb

questions.text: Compression of a nerve within the carpal tunnel produces inability to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oppose the thumb

  • Abductor pollicis brevis (producing abduction of thumb) and opponens pollicis (producing opposition of thumb) are paralyzed in low median nerve palsy (in carpal tunnel). So, opposition of thumb is lost.
  • Abduction of thumb can be also carried out by abductor pollicis longus supplied by radial nerve.
  • Flexor pollicis longus will be intact to carry out flexion at thumb phalanx as it is supplied by AIN nerve branch of median nerve above carpal tunnel and adductor pollicis will cause adduction as it is supplied by ulnar nerve.

1. Injury or compression of median nerve at wrist (e.g. Carpal tunnel syndrome) can be tested by

- Pen test for abductor pollicis brevis there is inability to touch the pen kept above the palm by thumb abduction.

2. Ape thumb deformity (In median nerve palsy, the thumb is adducted and laterally rotated and lies in same plane as rest of finger, due to unopposed action of extensor pollicis longus (radial nerve) and adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).

3. Loss of opposition

4. Sensory loss lateral 3½ of digits and 2/3 palm (autonomous zone is tip of index and middle finger).

5. Anterior dislocation of lunate may cause median nerve compression, making its reduction an emergency

Kiloh-Nevin sign (Flexor Digitorum Profundus-lateral 1/2 and Flexor Pollicis Longus) supplied by anterior interosseous nerve.

The pinch of thumb and index finger is strong if AIN is intact and this is called as Kiloh-Nevin sign.

Note: AIN supplies: Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) + Pronator quadratus (PQ) + Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) (Lateral 1/2).

questions.text: A 34 yr woman presents for pre-conception counselling. Her medical history reveals a history of depression and a prior child with a VSD. She reports that she takes medication for depression but she does not know the name. Which medication could have been responsible for the cardiac defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paroxetine

SSRIs in pregnancy:

  • Paroxetine: Associated with cardiac defects (mainly VSD)
  • Exposure to SSRIs > 20 weeks: increased risk of primary pulmonary HTN
  • Approximately 25 percent of neonates exposed to SSRIs in late pregnancy manifest one or more nonspecific findings considered to represent poor neonatal adaptation. These are collectively termed the neonatal behavioral syndrome which includes jitteriness, irritability, hyper- or hypotonia, feeding abnormalities, vomiting, hypoglycemia, thermoregulatory instability, and respiratory abnormalities.

 

Ref: Page 411, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A young man complaints of pain in the lower back, his X-rays are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ankylosing Spondylitis

Ankylosing Spondylitis Diagnostic Criteria–Modified New York Criterion

  • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
  • Supporting criteria: one of these three Inflammatory back pain
  • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
  • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).

Inflammatory back pain is classified if

4/5 are present

  1. Pain for > 3 months
  2. <40 Years age
  3. Insidious onset
  4. Pain improves with exercise
  5. Pain at night.

questions.text: You are a paramedic responding to a 911 call for an adult male who has collapsed and is unresponsive. You arrive on the scene to find the patient lying on the floor with no pulse and no breathing. You quickly begin CPR with a bag-valve-mask device and request your partner to attach a defibrillator. After delivering a shock, you resume CPR and ask your partner to prepare the medications. What is the first medication given during cardiac arrest in the Advanced Life Support algorithm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Epinephrine

Epinephrine is the first medication given during cardiac arrest in the ACLS algorithm. It is a vasopressor that helps to increase blood pressure and coronary perfusion during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that is given to treat ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia after defibrillation.

Atropine is a medication that is used to treat symptomatic bradycardia.

Sodium bicarbonate is given to correct metabolic acidosis, which may occur during prolonged cardiac arrest.

However, epinephrine is the first medication given during cardiac arrest in the ALS algorithm to help improve perfusion to vital organs during CPR.

questions.text: A 27 days old male baby was brought to the casualty. The mother complains that the child has projectile vomiting since 2 days and while bathing the child a mass is felt on the abdomen.  On proceeding with Ultrasonography ‘target sign’ was noted and on blood examination Serum potassium levels were found to be decreased and acidic urine is noted. Which drug may have a prenatal role in development of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Erythromycin

The Child is presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting with a palpable mass in the abdomen with hypokalemia and paradoxical aciduria and Ultrasonography showing target sign, these are suggestive of IHPS (Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) maternal intake of Erythromycin can cause IHPS.

Definitive treatment: Ramstedt Pyloromyotomy.

Option A- penicillin is not proven to cause any major side effects in pregnancy

Option B- dexamethasone is used in cases of premature delivery to progress lung maturity

Option C- Lithium can cause teratogenic side effects like Ebstein’s anomaly not the IHPS.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Chapter- 355– Page No- 7733.

choices.text: Seen most commonly in lower part of leg, in the gaiter area
Cause is due to ambulatory venous hypertension
Active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6

questions.text: All of the following are true about venous ulcer except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Has punched out edges

Venous ulcer has sloping edges.

The cause of a venous ulcer is ambulatory venous hypertension.

A venous ulcer usually has a gently sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by a variable amount of slough and exudate.

Venous leg ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle.

The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf, but may develop anywhere in the gaiter area. 

A healed venous ulcer is C5 of CEAP classification, while an active ulcer is C6.

questions.text: Free radial artery forearm flap (FRAFF) is a type of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciocutaenous flap

The forearm flap is a fasciocutaneous flap based on the fasciocutaneous perforators from the radial artery. The number of perforators is greatest between 12 and 20 cm from the takeoff of the radial artery, and these are the vessels captured in the distally located skin paddle

Common free tissue transfer donor sites

  • Muscle only: Latissimus dorsi, Rectus abdominis, Gracilis
  • Myocutaneous: Latissimus dorsi, Transverse rectus abdominis
  • Fasciocutaneous: Radial forearm flap, Scapular, Lateral arm, Anterolateral thigh, Groin
  • Osseous: Fibula (may be cutaneous as well), Forearm (taking sliver of radius bone), Iliac crest
  • Fascial: Temporoparietal.

questions.text: A 24y P1 presents for her postpartum visit after delivering an infant with an anomaly as shown below. You counsel her that she should initiate 4mg of folic acid daily for at least 1 month prior to her next conception. She asks how this would help. You tell her this will reduce her risk of developing a similar birth defect by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 70%

  • Folic acid supplementation in early pregnancy can lower neural-tube defect risks
  • More than half of all neural-tube defects can be prevented with daily intake of 400 µg of folic acid throughout the periconceptional period
  • A woman with a prior child with a neural-tube defect can reduce the 2- to 5-percent recurrence risk by more than 70 percent with a daily 4-mg folic acid supplement taken during the month before conception and during the first trimester.
  • As emphasized by the American Academy of Paediatrics and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (2017), this dose should be consumed as a separate supplement and not as multivitamin tablets.

 

Ref: Page 491, Williams 26th edition

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-month-old child for a routine paediatric follow up. She complaints that her child is having chronic diarrhoea for more than a month since she weaned her off from breast milk and started her on supplementary feeds. On examination the child has abdominal distension and facial pallor. Routine CBC reveals the presence of severe anaemia. On further evaluation she is found to have hypersensitivity to gluten in her foods. Which of the following specific antibody can be seen in the condition this child is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anti endomysial antibody

The diagnosis based on the clinical features is Celiac disease.

Most all patients with celiac disease express (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, which facilitate the immune response against gluten proteins (gliadin).
• Gluten is present in → barley, rye, oat, wheat
• Resulting in loss of bowel villi
• Associated with dermatitis herpetiformis

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Abnormal liver function
  • Vomiting
  • Iron-deficiency anaemia
  • Neurologic dysfunction
  • Constipation
  • Nausea
  • Common
  • Diarrhea
  • Fatigue
  • Borborygmus
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal distention
  • Flatulence

Diagnosis of Celiac Disease:

  • Clinical Findings
  • Small Intestines Mucosal Biopsy
  • Gluten Re-challenge

Serologic testing:

  • IgA antigliadin antibodies
  • IgA endomysial antibodies
  • IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies

Management of Celiac Disease:

  • Gluten avoidance is the mainstay of treatment
  • Prior to the introduction of a strict gluten-free diet, prognosis was very poor.

Option A, C and D are not most commonly seen in case of Celiac disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is having a history of severe pain in right eye. On fluorescein staining and slit lamp examination, irregular ulcer is visible. Corneal sensation is markedly decreased. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acyclovir

Given picture is suggestive of Dendritic ulcer which is a pathognomonic for Herpes viral keratitis.

Doc for herpes keratits: Acyclovir

Other drugs are Valcylovir
The mainstay of therapy is antiviral treatment either in the form of oral administration of acyclovir or valacyclovir or famciclovir for 10 to 14 days and/or topical antiviral medications.

Topical steroids are contraindicated in the presence of active epithelial disease

Specific treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical drugs: Natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops against Aspergillus and Fusarium and nystatin against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Oral ketoconazole or voriconazole for ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or with suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Non-specific supportive treatment:

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in all types of corneal ulcer.

  • Atropine (1% drops or ointment should be instilled in the affected eye two or three times a day (prevents complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation).

choices.text: Failure of closure of anterior neuropore
Failure of closure of posterior neuropore

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida during her pregnancy missed most of her ANC follow up sessions as well as prenatal medications. After delivery, her fetus was found to have a congenital deformity that presented as shown in image. This given congenital deformity is due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Failure of closure of posterior neuropore

Option A:  Failure of closure of anterior neuropore results in: Anencephaly

Option B:  Failure of closure of posterior neuropore results in:

  1. Spina bifida occulta Q
  2. Meningocele
  3. Meningomyelocele
  4. Posterior rachischisis

In given image abnormal mass is seen on lower side of spinal cord hence it is related to posterior neuropore defect.

Option C & D: Abnormality is seen only at lower part of spinal cord hence option C & D are excluded.

 

Development of CNS: It occurs from neural tube which is ectodermal in origin.

  • EctodermQ à neuroectodermQà neural plate Qà neural grooveQ à neural tubeQ à cranial part of neural tube forms brainQ and caudal part forms spinal cordQ.
  • During neural tube formation it fuses 1st at cervical regionQ.
  • Due to fusion there is formation of openings at cranial end and caudal end of neural tube known as anterior neuropore and posterior neuropore respectively.
  • Anterior neuropore is closed on – 25th day of IUL Q.
  • Posterior neuropore is closed on –28th day of IUL Q.
  • Neural tube defect: If neural tube is failed to close then it is known as neural tube defect. One of the common cause is folic acid deficiency. Hence folic acid Q tablets are recommended to lady before the conception.
  • 2 types of neuropore defects:
    1. Anterior neuropore defect- common manifestations are:
  1. Anencephaly
  2. Craniorachischisis 
  1. Posterior neuropore defect- common manifestations are:
    1. Spina bifida occulta
    2. Meningocele
    3. Meningomyelocele
    4. Posterior rachischisis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of sudden onset pain, redness and diminution of vision for 3 days. On indirect ophthalmoscopic evaluation, dense vitritis is present and fundus details are not clearly visible. Fundus picture is given below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Toxoplasma chorioretinits

Fundus picture suggestive of head light in fog appearance characteristic for toxoplasma chorioretinitis.

Toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of infectious retinochroiditis in humans.

Systemic Pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, and corticosteroids -This is the classic triple therapy used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis. Systemic Clindamycin is added to the previously mentioned therapy. In general, treatment is given until the inflammatory reaction begins to decrease and the retinal lesion shows signs of healing, which is usually 4 to 6 weeks.

questions.text: What is the significance of the drumstick shaped structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sex

The image marked is the Davidson body. It can be used to identify the sex.

Nuclear Sexing can be done by 4 methods:

  1. Barr body (sex Chromatin):
  • Condensed inactivated single X chromosome
  • Found in all nucleated cells but easily seen in Buccal smear, saliva, skin, hair follicles
  • Small planoconvex mass near the nuclear membrane
  1. Davidson Body:
  • A drumstick shaped body attached to nucleus of neutrophils
  • % of cell is Males and Females showing barr body and Davidson body

  1. Quinacrine Dihydrochloride: for staining Y chromosome
  2. Fluorescent Feulgen reaction: For staining X chromosome

 

Ref: Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 105

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

 

Then the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels to open, so that the ratio of conductance shifts far in favour of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance. This allows very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.

Consequently, the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

questions.text: True about WHO-SAGE criteria for HPV vaccination in an immunocompromised woman is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2-3 doses

[Ref. One-dose HPV vaccine offers solid protection against cervical cancer, 11 April 2022 News release, WHO]

SAGE recommends updating dose schedules for HPV

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20

questions.text: The type of enzyme inhibition in which Succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate is an example of:

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral white pupillary reflex. On slit lamp examination, there is a zone of opacity around fetal nucleus with spokes of wheel like arrangement towards center. The most probable diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lamellar cataract

Lamellar cataract is the most common vision affecting congenital cataract. Overall the most common congenital/developmental cataract is Blue Dot cataract.

choices.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon
It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon
It will remain attached to the tRNA as it cannot be used for protein synthesis
It will be chemically converted to cysteine by cellular-enzymes

questions.text: A tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry cysteine (tRNAcys) is mischarged, so that it actually carries alanine (ala-tRNAcys). Assuming no correction occurs, what will be the fate of this alanine residue during protein synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon

Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase enzyme attaches amino acid & tRNA and this step is the only proofreading step in translation.

If wrong amino acid gets attached during this step, then it can be corrected but if correction will not occur in this step, then this wrong amino acid will be added in the protein.

tRNAcys is usually recognized by the aminoacyl tRNA synthetase for cysteine and charged with Cysteine to produce cystRNAcys. As per the question, Alanine is incorporated to the tRNAcys to produce alatRNAcys. Ribosomal machinery can’t detect the amino acid attached to the tRNA.

Interaction between the codon of mRNA and anticodon of tRNA determines the amino acid incorporated in the polypeptide chain. So, Anticodon of alatRNAcys will interact with codon of Cysteine and hence Alanine will be incorporated in the polypeptide in place of Cysteine.

 

Reference: Harper 32/e: p 406-407

questions.text: A 28-year-old female has the sudden onset of severe chest, back, and abdominal pain. On physical examination, she is afebrile. She has no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly. She has right upper quadrant tenderness. Her peripheral blood smear is shown as in the image. Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pigmented gallstones

The history and image is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia and so, the patient has higher chances of pigment gallstone formation.

questions.text: While playing with his friends in the garden, a child ingests an unknown fruit. After a few hours, he is noticed to be irritable, and unable to pass urine and stools. The parents suspect the fruit was poisonous. Identify the possible poison and its antidote?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Datura and physostigmine

Datura:

  • Given history is suggestive of poisoning with anti- cholinergic poison.
  • Datura is a deliriant that produces anti- cholinergic effects.
  • Active principles – Hyoscine & atropine (seeds are very toxic)
  • Clinical features of datura poisoning:
    • Dry skin
    • Dry mouth
    • Dysarthria
    • Dysphagia
    • Dysuria – urinary retention
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium (muttering)
    • Dilated pupils
    • Death
  • Antidote of datura – physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier]

Yellow oleander/ cerbera thevetia

  • Cardiotoxic plant; most important feature is cardiac arrhythmia.
  • Active principles – Thevetin / Thevetoxin A & B / cerberin / Peruvoside / Ruvoside / Nerigolin
  • MOA – inhibits Na+2-K+-ATPase pump resulting in hyperkalemia [similar to Digoxin]

Rx - Digibind

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lateral and upward gaze

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

choices.text: ATP sensitive K+ channels

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman eats a high carbohydrate meal. Her plasma glucose concentration rises, and this results in increased insulin secretion from the pancreatic islet cells. Glucose mediated insulin release is mediated through:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ATP sensitive K+ channels

ATP-sensitive K+ channels are ion channels that are found in many types of cells, including pancreatic beta cells, which produce insulin. These channels are regulated by the levels of ATP and ADP in the cell, and they play a key role in regulating insulin secretion in response to changes in blood glucose levels.

When blood glucose levels are high, glucose enters the pancreatic beta cells and is metabolized to produce ATP. This increase in ATP levels causes the KATP channels to close, which leads to depolarization of the cell membrane and the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels. The influx of calcium triggers the release of insulin from the beta cell into the bloodstream.

Conversely, when blood glucose levels are low, there is a decrease in ATP levels, which causes the KATP channels to open. This leads to hyperpolarization of the cell membrane and a decrease in calcium influx, resulting in reduced insulin secretion.

The regulation of insulin secretion by KATP channels is important for maintaining glucose homeostasis in the body. Dysfunction of these channels can contribute to the development of diabetes mellitus, a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by high blood glucose levels.

Some drugs used to treat diabetes, such as sulfonylureas and meglitinides, work by binding to and activating KATP channels, thereby increasing insulin secretion. Other drugs, such as metformin, work by inhibiting ATP production, which indirectly stimulates KATP channels and insulin secretion.

choices.text: Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate
It must be reabsorbed by the kidney
Its urinary concentration must be higher than its plasma concentration
Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

questions.text: If a substance appears in the renal artery but not in the renal vein:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

Renal clearance refers to the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of a particular substance by the kidneys per unit time. It is a measure of the kidney's ability to remove a substance from the blood and excrete it in the urine.

The renal clearance of a substance can be calculated using the following formula:

Renal clearance = (U x V) / P

U= urine concentration of substance

V= urine flow rate

P= Plasma concentration of substance

  • Only Filtration – e.g. Inulin, Creatinine (Clearance = GFR)
  • Filtration + Complete Secretion (Clearance = RPF)
  • Filtration + Complete Reabsorption (No Clearance, Clearance = zero)
  • PAH > Cr. > Inulin > Urea > Na+ & H2O > Glucose, AA.

questions.text:
Match the following anti-glaucoma drugs with their mechanism of action:

 

P) Timolol

Q) Netarsudil

R) Latanoprost

S) Dorzolamide

 

  1. Inhibits carbonic anhydrase
  2. Increases aqueous outflow through the uveoscleral pathway
  3. Reduces aqueous humor production
  4. Reduces intraocular pressure by increasing trabecular outflow
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P3, Q4, R2, S1

 

  • Timolol (P) is a beta blocker that reduces the production of aqueous humor by blocking beta receptors in the ciliary body (1).
  • Netarsudil (Q) is a rho kinase inhibitor that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular pathway (4).
  • Latanoprost (R) is a prostaglandin analogue that increases the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway by relaxing the ciliary muscle and expanding the trabecular meshwork (2).
  • Dorzolamide (S) is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces the production of aqueous humor by inhibiting the activity of carbonic anhydrase in the ciliary body (3).

questions.text: Correct about Brown-Sequard syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Complete LMN type paralysis on same side at the level of lesion

Brown-Séquard syndrome is a neurological condition that results from damage to one half of the spinal cord. This condition is characterized by a specific pattern of motor and sensory deficits on the affected side of the body.

Because the anterolateral spinothalamic tract crossover to opposite side at the same segment or 2-3 segment above in the spinal cord while dorsal column crossover in the medulla

The symptoms of Brown-Séquard syndrome include:

  • Functions of tracts involved -

Dorsal column à ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception, stereognosis, graphesthesia

Spinothalamic tract à contralateral pain and temperature sensation

Corticospinal tract à primary motor activity same side of the body.

Paralysis or weakness on one side of the body

  • Loss of sensation (numbness or tingling) on the opposite side of the body
  • Loss of proprioception (the sense of knowing where one's body is in space) on the same side as the motor deficit
  • Hyperalgesia (increased sensitivity to pain) and allodynia (pain in response to non-painful stimuli) on the same side as the sensory deficit

Loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side, and 3) has loss of pain and temperature on the contralateral side.

choices.text: Vocal cord lies paramedian in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Both vocal cords lie paramedian in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Sensation below the level of vocal cords is lost in bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy
Kashima procedure is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

questions.text: Laryngeal paralysis – false statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sensation below the level of vocal cords is lost in bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy

It is bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, not superior.

Unilateral RLN palsy – All muscles other than cricothyroid are paralysed on one side. As SLN supplies cricothyroid which is a tensor as well as adductor, it pulls VC slightly medially à paralysed VC in paramedian (sometimes adduction will be quite enough to bring the paralysed cord till median position). Other VC is normal and will be able to compensate this small 1.5mm gap on the paralysed side. So, phonation will be normal. No aspiration seen. Rx – conservative.

Bilateral RLN palsy – Both VC come to lie in median position. Because all intrinsic muscles are paralysed on both sides except cricothyroids as they are supplied by SLN. But their action is adduction and tension. Hence they try to pull the vocal cords medially causing airway obstruction. (This is called as Wagner and Grossman theory). Patient presents with stridor in a life-threatening condition. Emergency tracheostomy is required to restore the airway. 6 months later, if shrinking of VC does not occur, surgical management done which include lateralisation thyroplasty (isshiki type II), cordectomy (by CO2 laser), posterior transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation), laryngeal re-innervation procedures like nerve muscle implant.

Bilateral SLN palsy – Both cricothyroids paralysed à both vocal cords lost tension à both VC bowed/curved à weak, husky voice. Also sensation above the level of vocal cords is lost on both sides à Aspiration risk is high. Rx – Tracheostomy and epiglottopexy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.   • Zidovudine (AZT) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is commonly used in the treatment of HIV infection. questions.text: The migrating motor complex in humans:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Requires an intact intrinsic nervous system for coordinated propagation

Migrating motor complexes (MMC) are a series of coordinated contractions that occur in the stomach and small intestine during the inter-digestive period, which is the time between meals. These contractions serve to clear any residual food, bacteria, and debris from the digestive tract and prepare it for the next meal hence called as broomstick of GIT.

It starts from stomach, each MMC lasts for 90-110 mins. MMCs are regulated by a complex interplay of hormones, neural signals, and intrinsic pacemaker cells in the gastrointestinal tract.

The MMC is divided into four phases:

Phase I: This is a period of quiescence or low-level activity in the gastrointestinal tract, which lasts for about 60-90 minutes after a meal.

Phase II: This is a period of irregular contractions that gradually increase in intensity and frequency, lasting for about 20-30 minutes.

Phase III: This is the most active phase of the MMC, characterized by high-amplitude contractions that sweep through the stomach and small intestine, lasting for about 5-15 minutes.

Phase IV: This is a period of quiescence that follows phase III, lasting for about 90-120 minutes before the cycle begins again with phase I.

questions.text: In a dog blood pressure experiment, a researcher injected phentolamine first followed by epinephrine and the recordings of the effect are shown in the diagram given below. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vasomotor reversal of Dale

  • Normally epinephrine produces a biphasic response on blood pressure which is characterized by increase in BP followed by decrease in BP. First increase is due to stimulation of alpha 1 receptor and later on decrease is due to stimulation of beta 2 receptors.
  • However, if alpha blockers like phentolamine are already given and then we administer epinephrine, it causes only exaggerated fall in blood pressure. This is called vasomotor reversal of Dale.
  • If we give same dose of a drug repeatedly and there is decrease in effect of the drug, it is called tachyphylaxis. It is shown by drugs like ephedrine.
  • There is no term like phentolamine epinephrine coupling.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department following a penetrating injury to the abdomen. His blood pressure was 80/50 mmHg, heart rate was 120 beats per minute, and he appeared pale and diaphoretic. Imaging studies revealed a grade III liver injury with active bleeding. What is the appropriate management of a patient with liver injury following penetrating trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Operative management

The appropriate management of the patient with a grade III liver injury with active bleeding following penetrating trauma and unstable vital signs is operative management. This may involve packing, suturing, and/or resection of the liver. Close monitoring, fluid resuscitation, and transfusion may also be necessary. Non-operative management with angioembolization may be attempted in stable patients, but is not appropriate in this situation. Percutaneous drainage is not the primary treatment for liver injury.

Option A: Observation and supportive care are not appropriate for the management of liver injury following penetrating trauma, as this can lead to serious complications, including hemorrhage and biliary peritonitis.

Option B: For stable patients with liver injury following penetrating trauma, non-operative management with angioembolization may be appropriate. This involves the placement of a catheter into the hepatic artery to identify the bleeding vessels and then the injection of an embolic agent to stop the bleeding. Close monitoring, pain management, and transfusion may also be necessary. However, in cases of active bleeding or unstable patients, operative management may be required.

Option C: Operative management is appropriate for unstable patients with liver injury following penetrating trauma or patients with significant ongoing bleeding or biliary leak. This may involve packing, suturing, and/or resection of the liver. In some cases, a liver transplant may be necessary.

Option D: Percutaneous drainage may be appropriate for patients with liver abscess or biloma following penetrating trauma, but it is not the primary treatment for liver injury itself.

questions.text: Number of recommended Ante-natal visits minimum, as per WHO guidelines, are?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 8

  • WHO recommends pregnant women to have their first contact in the first 12 weeks’ gestation, with subsequent contacts taking place at 20, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38 and 40 weeks’ gestation.

 

Ref. WHO Website

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of bipolar disorder presents to the clinic with complaints of confusion, agitation, diarrhoea, hand tremors, and excessive thirst. The patient reports taking lithium for the past year as part of his treatment plan. On examination, the patient has a fine tremor in both hands and is noted to have a serum lithium level of 1.8 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lithium toxicity

  • Lithium is a commonly used medication for the treatment of bipolar disorder. While lithium is effective in stabilizing mood, it can also cause a number of adverse effects, including lithium toxicity, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, hypothyroidism, and seizures.
  • Lithium toxicity can occur at serum lithium levels above 1.5 mEq/L and can lead to symptoms such as confusion, agitation, hand tremors and diarrhea. This can be a serious and potentially life-threatening complication that requires immediate treatment.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a rare but serious adverse effect of lithium use that can cause excessive thirst, urination, and dehydration. This occurs due to the effects of lithium on the kidneys, leading to reduced ability to concentrate urine.
  • Hypothyroidism is a common adverse effect of long-term lithium use, occurring in up to 20% of patients. Symptoms of hypothyroidism can include fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and depression.
  • Seizures are a rare but serious adverse effect of lithium use, occurring in less than 1% of patients. Patients with a history of epilepsy or seizure disorders may be at higher risk for lithium-induced seizures.
  • Therefore, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is A) Lithium toxicity, given the high serum lithium level and the presence of symptoms such as confusion, hand tremors, and excessive thirst.

questions.text: A 34-year-old multigravida presents for her 1st prenatal visit. She is 9 weeks and says she feels more nauseous than her earlier pregnancies. She has an ultrasound which shows the following images. What would be the likely genetic study on the products of conception?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 46XX

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOD (69XXX or 69XXY)
    • They are formed when 2 sperms fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component are found
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ovum and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis

OR

  • 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum
  • 46XX or 46XY
  • Only paternal component; No maternal component.

questions.text: A 22-year-old soldier is brought in by fellow squad-mates after collapsing during rigorous marching and he appears delirious in AIIMS emergency. Rectal temperature shows 104.4°F. You start cooling measures. At what temperature will you stop cooling?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 101.5°F - 102.0°F

Patient is likely suffering from exertional heat stroke.

Patients who are suffering from heat stroke should be rapidly cooled with ice water until their temperature is 101.5-102°F or they begin to shiver.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers - Peripheral edema and flushing
ACE inhibitors - Dry cough and hyperkalemia

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a correct match regarding the adverse effects of cardiovascular drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nitroglycerin - Tachycardia and hypertension

 

  • Nitroglycerin is a vasodilator that is commonly used to treat angina and heart failure. Its adverse effects include headache, dizziness, hypotension and reflex tachycardia, but it typically does not cause hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta-blockers - Bradycardia and hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol and propranolol, are commonly used to treat hypertension, angina, and heart failure. Their adverse effects include bradycardia, hypotension, and fatigue.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers - Peripheral edema and flushing: Calcium channel blockers, such as amlodipine and nifedipine, are also commonly used to treat hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias. Their adverse effects include peripheral edema, flushing, headache, and dizziness.

 

Option C. ACE inhibitors - Dry cough and hyperkalemia: ACE inhibitors, such as lisinopril and enalapril, are used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy. Their adverse effects include dry cough, hypotension, and hyperkalemia.

choices.text: The Friedman curve begins to flatten at 3-4 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true comparing the Zhang vs the Friedman curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In the Zhang curve, the active phase of labor begins at 6cm

  • Friedman’s curve was the initial labor curve at which active phase began at 3 cm
  • This changed to 4cm in the WHO modified partograph
  • Zhang et al, changed this to 6 cm and this is the basis of the WHO Labor Care guide (The net generation partograph).

choices.text: Varenicline is a nicotine replacement therapy that delivers nicotine through a transdermal patch
Varenicline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that is used to treat depression
Varenicline is a partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor that is used to aid smoking cessation
Varenicline is a long-acting beta2-agonist that is used to treat asthma

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding varenicline is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Varenicline is a partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor that is used to aid smoking cessation

 

  • Varenicline is a medication that is used to aid smoking cessation. It is a partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, which means that it binds to the receptor and activates it to a lesser extent than nicotine. This reduces the pleasurable effects of smoking and decreases nicotine cravings.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Varenicline is a nicotine replacement therapy that delivers nicotine through a transdermal patch: It is incorrect because varenicline is not a nicotine replacement therapy that delivers nicotine through a transdermal patch. Nicotine replacement therapies include nicotine gum, lozenges, patches, and inhalers.

 

Option B. Varenicline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that is used to treat depression: It is incorrect because varenicline is not a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are a class of medications that are primarily used to treat depression and anxiety disorders.

 

Option D. Varenicline is a long-acting beta2-agonist that is used to treat asthma: It is incorrect because varenicline is not a long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA). LABAs are a class of medications that are used to treat asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

questions.text: A 24 year old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes cesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

  • A common finding in severe pre-eclampsia/ eclampsia on imaging is PRES
  • PRES is a clinic-radiological syndrome characterized by headache, seizures, altered mental state and visual loss. It is characterized by white matter vasogenic edema affecting the occipital and parietal lobes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who received a kidney transplant three months ago presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, malaise, and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and a positive blood culture for cytomegalovirus. The patient's immunosuppressive regimen includes tacrolimus. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of tacrolimus that is most relevant to the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

  • Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressive medication that is commonly used in organ transplantation to prevent rejection. It works by inhibiting calcineurin, which is a protein phosphatase that is involved in the activation of T cells. By inhibiting calcineurin, tacrolimus blocks the production of cytokines such as interleukin-2, which are necessary for the activation and proliferation of T cells. This helps to prevent the patient's immune system from attacking the transplanted organ.

Option B. AMP kinase stimulation, is not a mechanism of action of tacrolimus. AMP kinase is an enzyme that is involved in cellular energy metabolism and is not directly related to immunosuppression.

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase inhibition, is the mechanism of action of another immunosuppressive medication called mycophenolate mofetil. IMP dehydrogenase is involved in the production of purine nucleotides that are required for DNA synthesis.

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase inhibition, is the mechanism of action of another immunosuppressive medication called leflunomide. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is involved in the production of pyrimidine nucleotides that are required for DNA synthesis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 pregnant female at 10 weeks of gestation presents with a two-week history of irritability and racing thoughts. She has been sleeping for only 2 hours per night. Recently, she got into a physical altercation with a colleague and threw her laptop at him. She has been working excessively, insisting that she wants to prove she is the "bestest employee" in the office. Her husband mentions that she has a history of similar episodes in the past but had been stable without medication for the past year. There is no history of substance abuse. What is the most appropriate intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Olanzapine

This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a manic episode during pregnancy. The symptoms include irritability, aggression (throwing laptop), racing thoughts, decreased need for sleep (sleeping for only 2 hours), and grandiose ideas (bestest employee).

A. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat manic episodes. It is considered relatively safe during pregnancy and is effective in managing the symptoms presented by the patient. Please remember that antipsychotics are preferred over mood stabilizers for managing mania in pregnant patients.

B. Lithium is the prototype mood stabilizer; however, its use during pregnancy carries a risk of congenital malformations, particularly Ebstein's anomaly, and therefore is not the preferred choice.

C. Valproate, another mood stabilizer, is not recommended during pregnancy due to its association with an increased risk of neural tube defects and other congenital malformations. Valproate must be avoided in pregnancy due to the high risk of neural tube defects.

D. Psychotherapy alone may not be sufficient to manage an acute manic episode in this patient, and a pharmacological intervention is necessary to stabilize her symptoms.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student is diagnosed with a pelvic mass and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level. She says that she was amenorrheic until she started taking combination oral contraceptive pills (COCs). She undergoes surgical exploration, and frozen section analysis of the surgical specimen reveals ovarian dysgerminoma. Which of the following is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Her karyotype is most likely 46XX

  • This is likely a dysgerminoma
  • Dysgerminomas occur in younger women and also in dysgenetic gonads
  • The tumor marker is LDH
  • In this patient, there is a history of primary amenorrhea which responded to combined E + P and this is likely swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis).

choices.text: Phase I trials are conducted in a small group of patients to evaluate the safety, dosage, and potential side effects of the new treatment.
Phase II trials are conducted in a small group of patients to evaluate its efficacy, optimal dosage, and safety.
Phase III trials are conducted to confirm the efficacy and safety of the new treatment compared to existing treatments or a placebo, as well as to evaluate its optimal dosage.
Phase IV trials are conducted after regulatory approval of the new treatment and involve monitoring its long-term safety and effectiveness in a large population.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with stage III breast cancer and her physician has recommended a new experimental drug for her treatment. The physician explains the different phases of clinical trials to the patient and her family. Which of the following is false about the different phases of clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phase I trials are conducted in a small group of patients to evaluate the safety, dosage, and potential side effects of the new treatment.

In Phase I trials, the new treatment is tested in a small group of healthy volunteers (not patients). It is done to determine the safety, dosage, and potential side effects of the treatment. The main purpose of this phase is to determine the safe dosage range of the new treatment, and to identify any potential side effects. Phase I trials involve a relatively small number of participants, typically less than 100 people.

Option B) Phase II trials are conducted in a small group of patients  to evaluate its efficacy, optimal dosage, and safety.

Option C) Phase III trials are conducted to confirm the efficacy and safety of the new treatment compared to existing treatments or a placebo, as well as to evaluate its optimal dosage. This phase involves a large number of participants, typically several hundred to several thousand, and is the final phase of testing before regulatory approval.

Option D) Phase IV trials are conducted after regulatory approval of the new treatment and involve monitoring its long-term safety and effectiveness in a large population. These trials are designed to collect additional information on the safety and effectiveness of the treatment, and to monitor for any rare or long-term side effects that may not have been detected in the earlier phases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman undergoes a robotic assisted hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and bilateral pelvic and paraaortic lymph node dissection. Her pathology reveals a grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with greater than 50% myometrial invasion, lymphovascular space invasion (LVSI), and positive washings. All the other pathology is benign. What stage is she assigned according to International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) criteria?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Stage IB

questions.text: 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to right upper thigh region. On examination, patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. On exploration - superficial femoral artery was transected. Which of the following is the suture material to be used for vascular repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polypropylene  

  • Polypropylene (Prolene) suture is a monofilament non absorbable suture. It comprises of isotactic crystalline steroisomer of polypropylene. It is blue in colour to enhance visibility. It elicits maximum tensile strength and minimal tissue reaction that does not cause tissue rupture.
  • It is preferred suture material for vascular anastomoses. It is neither absorbed not subjected to weakening by tissue enzymes, non-adhering, and biologically inert. Thus it is used for permanent fixtures.
  • Other uses are - general soft tissue approximation and ligation in cardiovascular, plastic, neurological surgeries and hernia repair
  • Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture. Copolymer of 90% glycol and 10% l-lactide. It retrains tensile strength of about 70% till 14 days after implantation, it is completely absorbed within 56-70 days by simple hydrolysis.
  • Poldioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture composed of polyester - p –dioxanone.  It is suitable for cases where extended would support and strength are required. It retains about 70% of initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely absorbed within 180- 210 days.
  • Delayed absorbable sutures like Vicryl and PDS are preferred for biliary and urological anastomosis where there is risk of foreign body inflammation and stone formation.
  • Vicryl is also known as work-horse suture of general surgery.

questions.text: Following a vaginal hysterectomy with anterior and posterior colporrhaphy for a 3rd degree uterovaginal prolapse, it is observed that the vault lies just above the introitus. Which additional procedure should be done to prevent vault prolapse in the future?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Sacrospinous fixation

  • Sacrospinous fixation of the vault is done at the time of a vault prolapse (The vault is anchored to the sacro-spinous ligament) to prevent vault prolapse
  • Abdominal sacrocolpopexy or laparoscopic sacrocolpopexy is done in a patient who presents with vault prolapse.

questions.text: A 38-year-old with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Estradiol level

Risk factors associated with the development of OHSS:

  • Young age (<35 years)
  • Low body mass index – asthenic habitus
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • History of atophy or allergies
  • Previous episode of OHSS
  • Pregnancy
  • Higher or repeated doses of exogenous human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone – agonist protocol
  • Use of Clomiphene citrate
  • Increased number of developing follicles (>35)
  • > 14 oocytes retrieved
  • Elevated serum estradiol (>2500 pg/ml).

questions.text: An 18-year-old with previously regular menses, presents with amenorrhea. She is also diagnosed with anorexia nervosa. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elevated neuropeptide Y level

  • Elevated neuropeptide Y levels have been found in women with anorexia nervosa
  • Anorexia nervosa is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • There is reduced FSH and LH levels and reduced E2 levels
  • Leptin is associated with obesity (not anorexia) and is implicated as a cause of puberty.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents with increasingly painful, cyclic menses since menarche 9 months ago. Oral analgesics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications no longer adequately control her dysmenorrhea. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. OHVIRA syndrome

  • The OHVIRA syndrome is obstructed hemivagina with ipsilateral renal agenesis and rare type of Mullerian anomaly associated with uterine didelphys.
  • As there is an obstructed hemivagina, there is dysmenorrhea which is progressive but the patient has periods as only half the vagina is obstructed.
  • In all the other 3 options, there will be primary amenorrhoea
  • In imperforate hymen and transverse vaginal septum, there will be cryptomenorrhea (there will be hematocolpos and hematometra but no visible bleeding).

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with acute onset watery diarrhea. The mother reports that the child had 6 episodes of diarrhea in the last 24 hours. The child has no fever, abdominal pain, or vomiting. The child is alert and well hydrated. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. What is the most common infectious cause of diarrhea in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rota virus

The most common viral infectious cause of diarrhoea is Rota virus.

Option A- Rhino virus is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infection in children

Option C- Noro virus is the most common cause of diarrhoea in adults

Option D- Zika virus will results in microcephaly.
